Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flow Physics of Aerodynamic Forcing in Unsteady Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jones, Anya
Proposal Number: 1553970

The proposed research is focused on the experimental investigation of the fundamental fluid dynamics phenomena that occur when a wing is subject to gusty flows. In unsteady flow, the gusts result in an additional buoyancy force (i.e., the added mass effect), as well as an unknown change in the flow structure and aerodynamic forcing due to the interactional aerodynamics. The PI has established experimental capabilities that allow her to explore these issues in detail. The results of this research could have an impact on the design of air vehicle wings and wind energy turbines.

Previous work on transient flows has focused on a wing driven in unsteady motion rather than the more realistic problem of a steady wing encountering sudden disturbances. The proposal is about identifying known and unknown mechanisms and phenomena, and about designing and conducting careful experiments to elucidate the unknown. For the flow regimes with large disturbances, a framework for a low-order model of separated flow will also be constructed, completing the approach to investigating these phenomena. There are also plans to reach out to K-12 students by demonstrating that science is exciting, fun, and to leverage outreach efforts with organizations like Women in Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this CAREER project was to apply tools from fundamental aerodynamics to characterize the changes in flow structure about a wing interacting with a strong transverse wind gust, and to predict the resulting aerodynamic force transients with a physics-based low order model. Some specific aims of the research activities were to (1) identify the physical mechanisms by which force and moment transients are produced during aggressive wing maneuvers and large-amplitude gust encounters, (2) characterize the physical similarities and differences between model-driven and flow-driven unsteadiness, (3) predict the evolution of the flow structure and aerodynamic forcing on wings undergoing an aggressive transient motion or encountering a large flowfield disturbance, (4) identify the characteristics of a gust encounter that most affect the flow structure and unsteady forcing on a wing, and (5) evaluate the parameter space over which analytical and low order force prediction models can be applied. 

Large amplitude transverse gusts, defined as gusts where the flow disturbance is of the same order of magnitude as the flight velocity, result in large transient excursions in lift, drag, and pitching moment. Force and moment histories are largely governed by the formation and shedding of strong leading-edge vortices, with stronger vortices shed during encounters with higher amplitude gusts. Strong gusts or high wing incidence can also result in the formation and shedding of trailing edge vortices on gust exit, thereby generating a transient lift reduction. Model-driven flows where the test model is maneuvered to produce a relative flow similar to a gust encounter can be a convenient test case but lack some of the underlying physics of a fluid-driven gust encounter. Notably, for a transverse gust encounter, a plunging rigid model does not account for the effects of gust entry, where the local angle of attack of a wing increases progressively along the wing chord as the wing passes through a stationary gust flow. For rigid wings encountering discrete large amplitude transverse gusts of width on the order of 2 lengths of the wing chord, the dominant parameters governing force production are the incidence of the wing and the shape and speed of the gust flow. Theoretical models based on potential flow work well to predict the results of these gust encounters for low amplitude gusts or gusts with a smooth velocity profile. Very high amplitude gusts that result in large scale flow separation violate the fundamental assumptions of potential flow, but these models may still provide a reasonable approximation of force production early in the gust encounter. Discrete vortex models are more robust and have aided in an exploration of pitching kinematics that can be used to lessen the impact of a large amplitude transverse gust encounter.
